data.text: Contents
Introduction

The main purpose of this policy is to ensure the safety of the patient and practitioner during venepuncture and to ensure there is standardised practice across Mid and South Essex (MSE) NHS trust. This policy outlines the minimum standard expected from clinical staff members who obtain venepuncture samples from patients receiving treatment and care within MSE.

This procedure can be performed by any accredited practitioner who has undertaken training and been deemed competent by assessment. This will include: Medical Staff / Registered Nurses and Midwives /Health Care Assistants, once they have completed their care certificate and probationary period/ or have completed the Trust competencies and any added ward based competencies) / Emergency Support Worker A&E (ESW)/Medical Emergency Assistants (MEA)/ Operating Departmental Practitioner (ODP) / Phlebotomists/Assistant Practitioners/Nursing Associates/ Members of the Research and Development Team/ Student Nurses/Degree Apprenticeship Nurses/ /RTTP Nurses.

It is expected that staff who undertake venepuncture must be employed in a clinical post within the Trust, however there may be exceptions to this including medical students, nursing/midwifery students; or members of the research and development team who are required to undertake venepuncture to support the delivery of research or drug trials.
Blood forms must be completed by staff that has been trained as per site expectations:
Scope

The purpose of this policy is to ensure all healthcare professionals responsible for undertaking Venepuncture within the Trust are provided with a clearly defined process by which their competence can be assessed to ensure their practice is safe and effective.
This document will provide guidance regarding who can undertake this skill; it will outline the procedure and the responsibilities of staff who undertake venepuncture within MSE NHS Trust.
Definitions

table_items.text: Venepuncture is the term used for the procedure of entering a vein with a needle for the purpose of obtaining a blood sample.
An accumulation of free blood anywhere in the body, that has partially clotted to form a semi-solid mass.
These are the 3 veins located on the back of the hand.
Arteriovenous Fistula is a surgically created connection between an artery and vein for haemodialysis, generally located in the arm.
The antecubital fossa is the shallow depression located before or, in front of, the median cubital vein of your arm.
The most commonly used blood collection devices that automatically draw a predetermined blood volume. (Bowen and Remaley, 2014)

The first blood collection bottle used when taking blood using a butterfly needle. This is used to prime the butterfly needle line ensuring air is omitted from the blood collection bottle. This bottle is removed from the vacutainer and discarded once the butterfly line is full of blood. The bottle does not have to be filled.
Online resource to recorded any incidences that occur.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Medical Director / Director of Nursing & patient safety are responsible for ensuring that patient safety and quality is maintained. They are corporately responsible for ensuring that this document is available and updated appropriately.
Assistant Director of Nursing/ Midwifery / Matron/Department Managers are responsible for the implementation of this document at ward level. This includes:
Identifying training needs
Ensuring staff are competent to undertake the procedure and maintaining competency records.

Medical staff: Senior clinical staff have overall clinical responsibility for patients. The Consultant will supervise medical staff in training to ensure that all patients have a documented medical management plan including the type and frequency of blood
sampling. The Consultant/Senior Clinician will be responsible for guiding clinical staff in their monitoring, interpreting and management of abnormal parameters in relation to blood results.
The People and Organisational Development Team/Practice Development Team are responsible for provision of Trust training programmes and maintaining the electronic staff record of training.

The Clinical Practice Education Facilitator/Practice Development Team is responsible for ensuring there is defined process for training and competency assessment relating to Venepuncture within the Trust and also aid staff in the clinical area with the competency assessment. Liaise with the Learning & Development Team for any additional training requirements.

Registered Nursing Staff/ Health Care Assistants (HCA's) /Phlebotomists/Student Nurses/Midwifes must be trained and deemed competent to undertake the procedure and comply with this document. A copy of the competency should be held by the individual and work place.
Reasons for venepuncture
To obtain a blood sample for laboratory tests for clinical management and health assessment (WHO, 2010)
To establish and monitor levels of medication
To monitor response to medical treatment and intervention
To screen for infection (Blood culture samples can only be taken by registered staff who have been trained to do so and been deemed competent), (Please refer to MSE Blood Culture policy)

To obtain a sample for the blood transfusion (WHO, 2010) (group and save and cross match samples can only be taken by staff trained and deemed competent for this particular test) (Please refer to MSE Manual of Blood Transfusion Policies and Procedures).
This policy does not cover:
Infection control

Hand Hygiene: The hands of Health Care Workers are the most common cause of transmission of microorganisms between patients, and are frequently implicated as the route of transmission in outbreaks of infection. Please follow the technique as stated in the MSE Hand Hygiene Policy. Staff must wash their hands before and after carrying out any invasive procedure such as Venepuncture. Hand decontamination using hand sanitiser must be performed before donning and removal of gloves (WHO, 2010).

Personal protective equipment – PPE: Single use non sterile gloves and a disposable plastic apron should always be worn when performing Venepuncture. These must be changed between patients. NB; Disposable surgical face mask to be worn for non AGP procedures, FFP3 mask for AGP procedures and for patients with Covid-19 and Multidrug resistant TB.

Disposal of Sharps: Sharps should be disposed of in an appropriate Trust approved sharps container (at the point of care) that is correctly assembled. Please refer to the MSE policy and procedure for the management of needle-stick, sharps and splash injuries. Where available, sharp safety devices must be used.
Accountability
Registered members of staff are responsible and accountable for their own actions.

Responsibility for non-registered staff (Health Care Assistants, Associate Practitioners, phlebotomists) lies with their line manager. All staff must ensure that their practice and scope is in line with their professional standards and Code of Conduct (NMC, 2018) where relevant.
Patient Identification
The practitioner must confirm the patient's identity verbally and by using the patient identity band (in-patients only). The following should be confirmed (without prompting):
Patients surname
Forename (in full e.g. Sam instead of Samuel is not acceptable)
Date of birth
1st line of address (where available)
Hospital number or NHS number (the patient may not know their hospital or NHS number)
The full patient data set should then be checked against the blood request form.
In incidences whereby the patient is unable to identify themselves (i.e. unconscious), confirmation of patient details should be made with their next of kin or identified carer,
if they are available, otherwise two qualified members of staff must check the patients name band individually. Please refer to the MSE Patient Identification Policy and Procedure.

Any discrepancies highlighted in the patient identification checking process i.e. incorrect details on wristband or the request form must be rectified immediately before proceeding in bleeding the patient. Escalate to Ward Manager/ Sister, document in the patients' healthcare records and complete a Datix.
Consent

Consent must be obtained by a person capable of performing the intervention or by a person who has been specifically trained to take consent for the intervention. Consent can be verbal, expressed or implied.
For consent to be valid, it must be voluntary and informed, and the person consenting must have the capacity to make the decision.

All staff undertaking Venepuncture must ensure their practice is in line with the MSE Consent to Examination or Treatment Policy, MSE Mental Capacity Act Policy and MSE Care Of Patients With Dementia Policy.

Staff undertaking Venepuncture should assess the patient's mental and physical status for confusion, cognitive behaviour and mental capacity to ensure they can make a specific decision at that time, prior to taking blood samples.

Where an in-patient with a learning disability is assessed to lack the capacity to consent to their care and treatment, a best interest decision should be made as part of a multi-disciplinary process. Application of the MSE Mental Capacity Act policy should be adhered to.

Where patients are agitated, but are able to consent to care and treatment, staff should consider involving relatives/carers who may be able to offer additional reassurance which may enable samples to be taken without causing undue distress to the patient.

If the patient or family do not speak English, arrangements must be made to ensure the procedure is understood and the consent is valid. The patient should be given a full explanation of procedure if necessary utilising the interpretation service available within the Trust.
Request form completion

In order to ensure a high standard of service to all our users it is imperative that an accurate and complete request form must accompany every sample. The forms must be printed or written clearly in black ink prior to the collection and used to verify the details of the patient at the time of collection.
Samples must not be taken from a patient if forms are incomplete.

Request forms are completed online via site specific online ordering services, accept for Blood Transfusion requests. All medical practitioners and nurse practitioner/team leader/midwifes are required to have completed site-specific training and have access granted via the IT self-service portal (Hornbill).
Basildon Hospital: Medway user training and Pathology Order Comms iLearn; Request access via hornbill self-service portal following these trainings.
For Blood Transfusion, complete the pink hand written request for group and save and blood products (Please refer to the MSE Manual of Blood Transfusion policy and procedures).
For all other blood sampling, request via Order Comms. Printing of the manual form is acceptable if the system is down or via telephone if samples already received and valid in the laboratory
Broomfield Hospital: Complete training via MEHT Review

For Blood Transfusion, complete hand written request form for Group and Save. Verbal requests can be made but two samples must go on record to issue non- emergency blood. The person completing and signing the top section of the form is held responsible for ensuring all these sections are completed and for the accuracy of the information given. This is usually a Doctor, some specifically trained nurses and registered Midwives can also complete this form. (Please refer to the MSE Manual of Blood Transfusion policy and procedures).
Southend Hospital: Complete ICE training via iLearn
All blood sampling requests are requested via ICE system. Manual forms are available if there is an IT failure.
The request forms must have the following patient/client identifiers before Venepuncture is performed:
Location at time of request
Consultant/GP
Patient forename and surname
Date of birth
Hospital/NHS number
Clear indication of what blood samples are requested
Full patient address (essential for outpatients)
For Transfusion request forms the following details must also be supplied the gender of the patient (at birth).
Assessment and preparation of the patient
The patient must be positioned so they are comfortable and safe. Visual inspection and palpation should be used to choose the most appropriate vein.

The preferred site of choice for Venepuncture should be the antecubital fossa. Venepuncture may be performed using other sites but this should be clearly documented in the patient's notes, with rationale, immediately following the procedure.
The staff must avoid using:

Veins that are hard, fibrosed or thrombosed or veins that are close to sites where there is infection, bruising or phlebitis, Extensive scarring from burns or surgery, Sites with noticeable skin conditions, such as eczema. (Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust, 2020)
Sites that are oedematous, or have had repeated Venepuncture or Cannulation (Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust, 2020)
Sites which may have been affected by injury (amputation, burns), disease (stroke, mastectomy, lymphedema) or treatment (fistulae for dialysis)(Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust, 2020)

Haematoma – A Venepuncture should not be performed on a haematoma, regardless of how small it may be. If there is not an alternate vein to draw, the Venepuncture should be performed distal to (below) the haematoma.

Peripheral infusion of fluids or medication - In normal circumstances, a blood sample should not be taken from the same site as an infusion line. This should only be done in extreme circumstances, with the agreement/advice of the responsible Doctor or nurse in charge. If a sample is taken from a limb in which an infusion line is sited, it must be taken distally to the infusion site if at all possible. Under no circumstances should an unqualified staff member (i.e. not NMC or GMC registered) alter or disconnect an intravenous infusion line. The tourniquet should be applied between the IV site and the Venepuncture site. If drawing above the IV site is the only option, then the IV infusion must be turned off for at least 30 minutes before performing the Venepuncture (this must be discussed with the relevant medical team looking after the patient prior stopping the infusion). As there is still a risk that the sample could be contaminated, you must document that the specimen was drawn above (proximal to) an IV site and how many minutes the IV was turned off before the draw occurred. The lab may reject the specimen as contaminated based on the test results.
AV Fistula or Vascular Graft – Only Trained Renal staff can access AV Fistulas.
Use of butterfly needle;

A safety butterfly needle with a vacutainer is always used when taking blood cultures. It may also be considered for patients with difficult, small or fragile veins. When using a butterfly needle for Venepuncture a discard tube should be used to draw blood into the butterfly needle line ensuring the air is expelled from the line. Once there are 2 to 3 drops of blood in the blood collection tube it can be removed from the vacutainer and discarded. The discard tube does not need to be completely filled, fill until the set tubing is full of blood. The discard tube must be discarded into near point sharps box.
When collecting blood using a butterfly needle, ensure the tubing it kept straight to prevent haemolysis.
Unsuccessful Venepuncture

If the staff have had two unsuccessful attempts of getting the blood from the patient, refer to another competent practitioner who can have a further two attempts, if the patient is consenting. If venepuncture has still been unsuccessful the patient should be reviewed by a senior doctor to determine alternative arrangements such as use of ultrasound scan or consideration for insertion of intravenous devices which allow for blood collection such as a central venous catheter.
Preparation of equipment

The staff must check expiry dates of all the equipment used for Venepuncture before they are used. Blood bottles must never be pre labelled. They must be labelled after the blood has been collected, at the patient's side as per National Patient Safety Agency guidelines.
Blood samples for transfusion must be labelled by hand (Please refer to MSE Manual of Blood Transfusion Policies and procedures) (additional training/assessment required).

Blood must be collected in the correct order of draw as this can affect the results if incorrectly taken (See Appendix 2). An adequate amount of blood must be obtained for the laboratory test to be carried out. If an insufficient sample is sent the test may not be able to be processed or may provide erroneous results (WHO, 2010)

Do not transfer blood from one tube to another, each tube is designed for specific tests and are run on different analysers, transferring blood from one to another can lead the sample results to be incorrect or cause the sample to be rejected.
Clinical governance

13.1 Any clinical incidents, patient complaints and patient feedback related to Venepuncture will be monitored by the individual practitioner's line manager, and reported through the relevant Best Practice Group.
Documentation
The blood collection bottles must be labelled whilst practitioner is still with the patient.

Blood collection tubes can be labelled using patient labels where this is available or handwritten using a black non-smudge pen.  Labels for group and save and crossmatch must be hand written  (please refer to the MSE Manual of Blood Transfusion policy and procedures).
All evidence relating to consent, discussion, advice and explanation must be documented in the patient's notes.
Delivering to

Once blood has been collected pathology laboratory, sample bottles and request form are complete; the samples must be sent to the pathology laboratory in a sealed bag and placed in the dedicated collection area.

For urgent samples, the pathology laboratory should be contacted to inform them of urgent bloods. The blood samples should be delivered by ward staff to a member of the pathology team. The request form should be labelled as URGENT.
Special consideration:
Preventing complications associated with venepuncture:

Preventing a Haematoma: puncture only the uppermost wall of the vein. Remove the tourniquet before removing the needle. Make sure the needle fully penetrates the upper-most wall of the vein; partial penetration may allow blood to leak into the tissue surrounding the vein. Adequate pressure should be applied to stop the bleeding once the phlebotomy is complete. A haematoma can cause a post-phlebotomy compression injury to a nerve.
Preventing Haemolysis: Mix tubes gently, by inversion, 5-10 times – do not shake them. Avoid drawing blood from a haematoma. Make sure the venepuncture site is dry. Avoid probing for the vein.

Preventing Haem-concentration: An increased concentration of larger molecules and formed elements in the blood may be due to several factors including prolonged tourniquet application (greater than 2 minute), massaging, flicking,
squeezing or probing the site, long-term IV therapy, and sclerosed or occluded veins.
Preventing injury to a nerve, tendon, or muscle: Use careful palpitation and appropriate angle of entry. Excessive probing (uncalculated side-to-side movement) with the needle should be avoided.

Preventing dizziness or fainting and potential follow-up injuries due to a fall: Be sure patient is seated in an appropriate chair and or lying in a bed. Pull the emergency buzzer to get additional help if patient has fainted.

Injury – Although rare, the nerve, artery or tendon may be punctured. This can cause pain, damage or excessive bleeding. This can be reduced by spending time ensuring the vein is identified before cleaning and commencing the procedure. Should this occur, stop, apply pressure, reassure the patient, obtain help from a second colleague if required, document in the patient's records. (Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust, 2020)
Preventing infection: Follow MSE infection control policies.
Venepuncture in children and young people under the age of 16:
For children under the age of 12 years, or under 16 years but of small build, a blue butterfly may be used
Use of a local anaesthetic cream, such as Ametop, or Ethyl Chloride Spray is advocated for children undergoing Venepuncture in order to minimise distress

It may be helpful to identify any child/young person with particular needs or phobias prior to the Venepuncture appointment to allow a play specialist worker to plan supportive intervention with the child and family.
Renal patients

17.1 In case of renal patients (Pre-dialysis) avoid using antecubital fossa and the non- dominant hand, metacarpal veins on the dorsum of the dominant hand should be the first choice. As antecubital fossa of the non-dominant hand is usually used for AVF creation.
Training requirements
All staff undertaking the Venepuncture must have a basic knowledge of:
The anatomy and physiology of the veins of the arm and hand
Assessment and selection of vein and appropriate equipment
Infection control, health & safety
Potential complication
Laboratory investigations

All staff within the Trust (with the exception of medical staff) must complete the Trust training. Venepuncture can be requested via the online learning platform. Access can be gained once the individual's manager has authorised the training. The online learning module for Venepuncture must be successfully completed prior to attending the practical teaching session. Please note; the online learning module allows learners three attempts to achieve the pass mark. Should the learner fail all attempts they should seek advice and learning support from their manager. They may not reapply within 6 months unless further learning has taken place. Competency paperwork will be provided following the theory training.

Medical staff are trained and assessed as competent during medical training; they are responsible for ensuring they remain up to date and familiar with Trust equipment. All new medical staff will be informed of this procedure on Trust induction.

Once staff has attended training they must undertake a period of supervised practice before being assessed for competence. Competency assessment may be undertaken by any person who is a registered Health Care Professional and who is competent in Venepuncture, has a sound knowledge of the policies and holds a recognised teaching and assessing qualification such as the Standards for Student Supervision and Assessment supervisor and assessor qualification.

Nursing staff / allied healthcare professionals who are new to the Trust and hold evidence of previous training and competency achievement may, after familiarisation with Trust Venepuncture policy, be assessed against Trust competencies at the discretion of the Senior Sister / Department Manager/ Practice Education Facilitators/Practice Development Team.

HCAs /APs/ AHPs / ETs /ODPs and other practitioners must have completed their relevant Trust competencies prior to Venepuncture training. Venepuncture competencies must be completed before staff are authorised to take blood without supervision.
Phlebotomists will be trained and deemed competent by Phlebotomy Supervisor.
Practitioners are responsible for maintaining their competency and should seek assistance should they become deskilled due to lack of practice.
Student Nurses/Midwives
Venepuncture for student nurses and midwives is a standard of proficiency required for completion of the student nurse/midwife training (NMC, 2018).

During the third year of training ONLY, Student nurses/midwives will be expected to undertake MSE trust training in form of a theoretical workbook followed by simulation practical training. Once the theoretical and simulation practice training has been completed the student nurse/midwife may practice this skill under supervision of a registered nurse/midwife who has completed the Standards for Supervision and Assessment training (Part 1 and Part 2).
Student nurses/midwives MUST always practice Venepuncture under supervision.
Please note:

To obtain blood sampling for cross-matching and Group and Save staff are required to complete additional online Trust training and practical assessment. Please read Manual of Blood Transfusion or equivalent.

For Blood Cultures please read and follow the Blood Culture Policy MSEPO-21030. Blood Cultures should only be collected by members of staff nominated by their line manager to be trained in the collection of adult blood cultures (medical, nursing/midwife, MEA's, EDA's, phlebotomists). Staff can only complete blood culture training if they are signed off as competent for Venepuncture. They must complete the online MSE Blood Culture course and complete supernumerary competency assessment prior to taking blood samples for cultures.
Monitoring and audit
19.1 Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Datix Cloud IQ For incidences regarding venepuncture

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Infection Prevention and Control Committee and Practice Education Committee which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local venepuncture guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Directors of Nursing of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 3)
References
Department of Health (2007) Saving Lives: Reducing Infection, Delivering Clean and Safe Care. DOH, London.

Nursing and Midwifery Council (2018) the NMC Code,  The Code: Professional standards of practice and behaviour for nurses, midwives and nursing associates - The Nursing and Midwifery Council (nmc.org.uk) Online [ Accessed 26.11.2021]
The Royal Marsden NHS foundation trust (2020) The Royal Marsden Hospital manual of clinical and cancer nursing procedures. Online https://www.rmmonline.co.uk/manual/c13-sec-0084 [accessed 23.11.2021]
World Health Organisation (2010) WHO guidelines on drawing blood: best practices in phlebotomy . Online WHO guidelines on drawing blood: best practices in phlebotomy [Accessed 26.11.2021].

Nursing and Midwifery Council (2018) Future nurse: Standards of proficiency for registered nurses. Online https://www.nmc.org.uk/globalassets/sitedocuments/standards-of- proficiency/nurses/future-nurse-proficiencies.pdf  [accessed on 18.11.2021]
Appendix 1: Procedure
In conjunction with the Royal Marsden Manual of Clinical and Cancer Nursing Procedures (2020)
Equipment Required
Patient Near point sharps disposal unit.
Clean Tray/Receiver
Single use disposable tourniquet.
Trust approved blood collection needle
Trust approved blood collection bottles
2% Chlorhexidine in 70% alcohol skin prep such as; clinell / sanicloth.
Gauze squares.
Hypo-allergenic tape. Specimen request forms.
Appropriate blood collection bottles.
Gloves; non-powdered, latex free.
Apron.
Hand sanitiser
Venepuncture policy and procedure / MSEPO-21195 / 1.0
Page  of

table_items.text: Explain procedure to patient and allow time for patient to ask questions, and obtain consent. Ask the patient to verbally confirm their name and date of birth (if they are able to do so) and check that this matches exactly with the request form. For in-patients, check that the patients details on the identity band match exactly with details on the request form (exceptions may apply to trauma patients in ED)
To obtain patients consent and co-operation so that patient is relaxed. To ensure that blood samples are obtained from the correct patient. Correct patient identification is essential.
Ensure the patient is comfortably positioned and supported in an area with adequate lighting, ventilation and privacy.
To ensure that both patient and operator are comfortable, that lighting is adequate to illuminate site of Venepuncture and that privacy and confidentiality is maintained.
Select an appropriate vein, and ensure device chosen is appropriate.
To reduce trauma to the vein, and suitable samples for analysis
Apply tourniquet 5-10 cm above intended site, and palpate vein to ensure suitability, then release.
To dilate veins by obstructing the venous return, allowing effective assessment and access.
Clean skin thoroughly with skin prep for approximately 30 seconds and allow drying naturally for 30 seconds– DO NOT re-palpate vein or touching the skin.
Assemble the vacutainer equipment necessary for Venepuncture and retract the needle guard observing aseptic non-touch technique.
To ensure the procedure is timely and maintaining asepsis
Decontaminate hands using hand sanitiser Apply gloves Re-apply tourniquet NB gloves can be applied prior to cleaning the site if appropriate
To protect yourself from body fluids
Anchor the vein by applying traction on skin a few centimeters below proposed site.
To immobilise the vein. To provide counter tension, allowing smooth entry of needle.
Warn the patient of a sharp scratch
To prepare the patient /avoid causing distress
Insert the Blood Collection Needle or butterfly smoothly at an angle of approximately 30 degrees.
To ensure that Venepuncture is successful with the minimum discomfort.
Level off needle/butterfly as soon as puncture of vein wall is felt.
To avoid piercing both sides of the vein
Advance needle/butterfly 1 mm into vein if possible.
To stabilise device within the vein and prevent displacement during Venepuncture.
Do not exert any pressure on the needle.
To prevent a through puncture occurring.
Collect blood samples using vacuumed tubes, following order of draw (Appendix 2) and checking the level of each sample.
To prevent contamination of subsequent samples. So the laboratory has sufficient blood to carry out the test requested.
Release the tourniquet. NB-The maximum time the tourniquet can be applied is 60
To decrease pressure within the vein, and reduce leakage on removing the needle.
Ensure the last blood collection tube has been removed from the vacutainer/butterfly
To prevent leakage of blood on removal of needle
Place gauze gently over puncture point and remove the
To avoid causing the patient pain.
needle. Do not apply pressure until the needle has been
Immediately after removing needle from vein, apply needle
safety cover by pushing the safety shield forward with thumb
on the thumb pad. If using a butterfly, advance safety cover
Dispose of sharps at point of use, into near point sharps bin
Pressure should be applied until bleeding has stopped – patient, if able, may apply pressure.
To prevent undue bleeding and bruising

Ensure correct amount in each blood collection bottle. Mix by inverting bottle as per guidelines, if there are additives in the bottle. (See Appendix 2 blood collection bottle System Mixing Guidelines and Tube Guide)
To ensure blood is correctly presented to the laboratory and the patient does not have to be re-bled.

Remove gloves and decontaminate hands using hand sanitiser prior to labelling Blood specimens must be labelled at the patient's side immediately AFTER the specimen has been taken, and complete final details on the blood request form. NEVER pre-label specimen bottles The person who identified the patient and collected the specimens must label the sample bottles with all the required information, sign the specimen and form and print name. In-patients samples must be labelled using information directly from the patient identification band. Never use healthcare records, prescription charts or other forms to label the specimens. Outpatients specimens must be labelled using information from the request form that has been confirmed as correct with the patient.
To prevent contamination To prevent specimens being labelled with another patient's details, and comply with NPSA.
Ascertain if patient requires a dressing to site.
To promote comfort and prevent entry of bacteria.
Dispose of all clinical waste in an orange bag.
Document the procedure in the patient's health record.
To ensure a record is kept of all procedures carried out for patient care.

A maximum of two attempts may be carried out by a single practitioner ensuring new equipment is used each time. If unable to obtain a blood sample, report this to the nurse in charge / supervisor, relevant doctor (or GP if an out-patient).
To prevent undue harm to the patient. To allow further assessment, and alternative arrangements to be made.

It is the responsibility of the person requesting the blood test to ensure the results are documented in the healthcare records, followed up and acted upon. If blood sampling has been delegated to a support worker, then the responsibility for documenting and acting on results remains with the accredited practitioner who delegated the procedure.
To ensure patient safety and that results are acted upon in a timely manner.

Appendix3: Preliminary equality analysis
This assessment relates to Venepuncture policy and procedure: (Please tick all that apply)

table_items.text: ☐ A change in a service to patients
☐ A change to an existing document
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Policy guidelines to reflect practice used across Mid and South Essex NHS Trust
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To Harmonise the strategies of the MSE 3 sites
Who benefits from this change and how?
Patients will benefit by receiving the same standard of care on all sites. Staff will benefit as they will be able to practice this skill across the sites to the same standard.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
Yes. I have consulted with the practice education nurses across the 3 MSE sites, Matrons and Infection Prevention and Control Committee.
